metadata.title: Title: 1 High-resolution influenza mapping of a city reveals socioeconomic determinants of 2 transmission within and between urban quarters 3 4

abstract.text: 162/150) 39 40 With two-thirds of the global population projected to be living in urban areas by 2050, 41 understanding the transmission patterns of viral pathogens within cities is crucial for effective 42 prevention strategies. Here, in unprecedented spatial resolution, we analysed the socioeconomic 43 determinants of influenza transmission in a European city. We combined geographical and 44 epidemiological data with whole genome sequencing of influenza viruses at the scale of urban 45 quarters and statistical blocks, the smallest geographic subdivisions within a city. We observed 46 annually re-occurring geographic clusters of influenza incidences, mainly associated with net 47 income, and independent of population density and living space. Vaccination against influenza 48 was also mainly associated with household income and was linked to the likelihood of influenza-49 like illness within an urban quarter. Transmissions patterns within and between quarters were 50 complex. High-resolution city-level epidemiological studies combined with social science surveys 51 such as this will be essential for understanding seasonal and pandemic transmission chains and 52 delivering tailored public health information and vaccination programs at the municipal level. 4 Introduction:

Transmission of influenza is influenced by extensive but poorly understood interactions between 55 various viral, host and environmental factors 1-3 . Influenza may serve as a model for pandemic 56 threats including the most recent COVID-19 pandemic. Whole viral genome sequencing has 57 enabled reconstruction of phylogenetic relatedness at high resolution. Using these approaches, 58 the interactions and dynamics of influenza transmission events have been described across a 59 range of scales: globally 4-6 , across continents 1,7 , in university campuses 8 , or within households 9-60 12 . With two-thirds of the global population projected to be living in urban areas by 2050, 61 understanding the transmission patterns of influenza within cities is crucial for effective prevention 62 strategies and may help to prepare for pandemic threats. Previous work identified cities as 63 containing critical chains of transmission outside of peak climatic conditions (Dalziel, B. D. et al 64 Science 2019), but the resolution to look at these critical intra-city transmission chains in detail 65 has until now been lacking. Very few studies have explored transmission events and dynamics of 66 influenza viruses at the scale of a city 13-17 . Cities are heterogeneous with remarkably different 67 neighbourhoods based on the socioeconomic position of the individuals living there.
Consequently, a high spatial resolution of the urban space and built environment is crucial to fully 69 understanding the impact of factors linked to health and disease 18,19 .
In this study we combine epidemiologic, geographical and demographical factors at the 72 unprecedented resolution of urban quarters (i.e. neighbourhood/area) and statistical blocks (i.e.
city block/street) levels, the smallest statistical enumeration areas within a city. Basel,

Switzerland, serving as our model city, we explored the local patterns of influenza distribution and 75 transmission from 2013 to 2018. Basel has urban quarters that differ substantially in 76 socioeconomic indicators and housing structure. By using information at the level of statistical 77 blocks, we were able to construct a detailed picture of influenza transmission within the city. We 78 visualized kernel density estimates of influenza cases (reflecting the clustering of cases), a 79 fundamental data smoothing method where inferences about the population are made, together 80 with various population-based factors on maps with high resolution. Cases were corrected for 81 population density and socioeconomic factors such as education levels, income and available 82 living space were then analysed. Furthermore, we complemented the data with a detailed 83 personal survey distributed to 30,000 households during the 2015/2016 flu season, to further 84 explore urban quarter-specific aspects of self-reported influenza-like illness and association to 85 socioeconomic factors. Finally, we described the details of influenza transmission during the 86 2016/2017 season using whole genome sequencing of all collected influenza viruses, covering 87 5 more than 650 isolates, combining the data, resulting in an unprecedented spatiotemporal 88 resolution. The details on the study design for this project have previously been published 20 . 89 90 Results: 91 Reoccurring influenza patterns within a city 92 The City of Basel has 19 urban quarters and a stable mean population of 175,350 inhabitants 93 during the 5-year study period (+/-1,737 inhabitants) (Figure S1A). A total of 1,078 statistical 94 blocks were identified within the city for the subsequent analysis. First, we collected epidemiologic 95 and geographic information of 1,715 PCR-confirmed influenza cases over five consecutive 96 influenza seasons from 2013/2014 to 2017/2018 and identified areas with a high burden of 97 influenza infections (Figure S1B-C). Influenza viruses isolated in Switzerland were similar to 98 viruses isolated across Europe in the study period (Table S1). On a weekly basis, we linked each 99 individual case of PCR-confirmed influenza to the patient's place of residence and anonymized 100 the data at the scale of statistical blocks. We determined both the kernel density estimates for 101 absolute influenza cases across all urban quarters and observed regional clusters of influenza 102 cases within the city across all five seasons (Figure 1A) with similar spatial patterns for each 103 individual season (Figure S1D-H).

We further explored the association between influenza occurrence and socioeconomic factors as 105 well as the built city environment. We linked socioeconomic scores to each statistical block 106 reflecting (i) the population density (inhabitants per hectare (ha)), (ii) the living space (per capita 107 in m 2 ), and (iii) the net income (median in CHF). Each of these three key factors was translated 108 to "socioeconomic points" ranging from one to five, which were added to generate a total 109 socioeconomic score for each housing block: a score of three reflecting the lowest and a score of 110 fifteen the highest possible socioeconomic value 20 (Figure S2A-D) . The median socioeconomic 111 scores of urban quarters ranged from three to ten. We observed that city areas with a high 112 socioeconomic score had fewer influenza cases in comparison to areas with lower socioeconomic 113 scores ( Figure 1B) . Figure 1C provides a representative example of the effect of population 114 density during the 2016/2017 influenza season comparing the urban quarters Gundeldingen (GU, 115 high population density with high influenza burden) with Bruderholz (BR, low population density 116 with low influenza burden). These two urban quarters are located next to each other but are 117 notably different. The urban quarter with small detached residential buildings (single family 118 homes) showed a mean socioeconomic score of 9.5 (+/-1.71 standard deviation) while the other 119 urban quarter with large (multifamily) residential buildings shows a mean socioeconomic score of 126 the level of statistical blocks across urban quarters during the examined influenza seasons 127 (Figure 1E-F, S3A-H, Supplementary file 1). Besides visualizations of influenza case 128 distributions, we further explored associations between socioeconomic factors and the influenza 129 incidence (corrected for the population density within each statistical block). The analysis included 130 all five seasons and data from all 1,484 statistical blocks for every year. We used a multivariable 131 Poisson regression and observed that net income of the statistical block (per 1,000 CHF) was the 132 strongest predictor for influenza incidence at the level of statistical blocks, independent of 133 population density and living space in most influenza seasons (Figure 1G, S4). 134 135 Socioeconomic factors determinate herd immunity 136 To further explore the interrelationship between socioeconomic factors and rates of influenza-like 137 illness, we conducted a detailed survey across ten urban quarters for the 2015/2016 season 138 (Figure S1A). The survey included 54 questions, addressing (i) influenza-like illness and 139 vaccination, (ii) aspects of the urban environment, (iii) access to health care information, (iv) 140 health related data, and (v) the place of residence at the level of statistical enumeration blocks.
The English version of the survey is attached as supplementary file (Supplementary File 2) .

The share of self-reported influenza-like illness cases fulfilling all three defining criteria for each 144 of the selected urban quarters ranged from 3.4% to 7.0% (n=358; median 4.5%) during the 145 influenza season 2015/2016 (Figure 2A; S5A) . The number of influenza-like illness and PCR-146 confirmed cases (71 influenza A and 44 influenza B) did not correlate in that particular season 147 across the explored statistical blocks responding to the survey (r=0.0144, p=0.7411; Figure S5B ).

However, the reported frequency of influenza-like illness corresponds to previously reported 149 attack rates of three to five percent 21-23 . Other respiratory viruses likely contribute to cases 150 matching the non-specific influenza-like illness definition. In our analysis, 20-25% of the influenza 151 PCRs performed on patients presenting an influenza-like illness are subsequently confirmed by 152 PCR-based diagnostics as indicated for the 2017/2018 influenza season (Figure S5C). 153 154 7 Next, we performed regression models with self-reported influenza-like illness as a binary 155 endpoint for each individual. The factors associated with increased relative risks for self-reported 156 influenza-like illness in stepwise forward and backward selection multivariable analysis were: ≥3 157 people per household and daily use of public transport. Of note, a total of 22.8% (1859 of 8149)

158 were from households with ≥3 people. Of which 81.3% (1511/1859) were couples or single 159 parents with children and 8.8% (720/8149) had children under the age of 7 years. The factors 160 associated with decreased relative risks were: vaccination against influenza, age more than 65 161 years, and daily physical activity ( Table 1; Table S2 ). The most protective variable against 162 influenza-like illness was vaccination. In a multilevel multivariable model, vaccination remained 163 the most important factor even when correcting for the urban quarter an individual lived in (RR 164 0.4, 95% CI 0.24 -0.67). Of note, people with and without self-reported influenza vaccination 165 showed similar odds ratios for symptoms of common cold (respiratory symptoms not fulfilling the 166 influenza-like illness case definition, such as running nose and sore throat; OR 0.98, 95% CI 0.78 167 -1.24).

The self-reported influenza vaccination rates were heterogeneously distributed at the level of 170 urban quarters (Figure 2B; S5D) . The median vaccine rate was 25.8% 171 throughout the city, which is in the range of the previously reported averages in Switzerland 24 .

We performed regression models with self-reported vaccination against influenza as binary 173 endpoint for each individual. The factors consistently associated with an increased likelihood for 174 self-reported influenza vaccination were people belonging to a risk group of chronic disease and 175 health care workers. Low household income (below 6000 CHF per month) was associated with a 176 significant lower likelihood of self-reported vaccination ( Table 2; Table S3 ). When adjusting the 177 multivariable model to specific urban quarters, low income was no longer correlated with 178 vaccination (p=n.s.), which confirms the previously mentioned profound difference of income 179 between urban quarters ( Figure S2C ).

The survey results confirm that vaccination against influenza has a protective effect against 182 influenza-like illness. The odds of acquiring influenza-like illness during the 2015/2016 season 183 were 3-times less in the group of vaccinated people (0.33 OR, 95% 0.24-0.46) in comparison to 184 non-vaccinated people. This correlates to reported vaccine effectiveness rates of 44% in children 185 and 78% in adults against influenza for the 2015/2016 season 25,26 (Table S4). The median self-186 reported vaccination rates between urban quarters showed a direct correlation with the 187 socioeconomic score of the respective urban quarter (R 2 =0.607, p=0.0079; Figure 2C) -the 9 CHF 54,144 vs. CHF 48,898, p=0.047; Figure S6C), whereas population density did not differ 222 (p=0.39). 223 224 225 Geographic patterns of influenza transmission within a city 226 Next, we studied the impact of geographic and socioeconomic factors on influenza transmission 227 using molecular epidemiological techniques. During the 2016/2017 season, we screened patients 228 presenting an influenza-like illness using an influenza-specific PCR. We included 663 influenza 229 virus positive samples recruited from 12 different study sites across the city ( 32 ; Figure S7A). The 230 largest cohort within a single city, to the best of our knowledge. First, we determined antibody 231 titres against the circulating H3N2 virus and other vaccine viruses in the patients, who having 232 presented within days of feeling sick still had high viral loads meaning that antibody levels could 233 be assumed to be close to baseline. Patients with PCR-confirmed influenza showed significant 234 lower antibody titres against influenza A H3N2 in comparison to patients without influenza, 235 highlighting the importance of protective antibodies (Figure S7B and S7C). Of note, antibody 236 titres against viruses not circulating (e.g. H1N1) where not significantly different between PCR 237 positive and negative patients.

238 239 A total of 663/858 viral genomes passed our duplicate and quality control filter (methods and 33 ) 240 and were included in subsequent analyses. 427/663 (64.4%) of isolates were from people living 241 in Basel and the remaining 236/633 (37.3%) isolates were people living outside of Basel, mainly 242
in surrounding villages within a 20km range but occasionally (n=6/633) from further away (e.g.

body_text.text: 6 as a surrogate marker for the population density and available living space in a particular area 122 and thereby also be an indicator of influenza burden ( Figure 1D ).

To account for this potential ecologic fallacy, we corrected the influenza incidence rates per 1,000 125 inhabitants for each statistical block. We still observed similar dense influenza case patterns at 8 higher the socioeconomic score, the higher the vaccine rate. Income showed the highest 189 correlation with vaccination rates, followed by living space and population density, respectively 190 (R 2 0.622, p=0.0067; R 2 0.618, p=0.007; R 2 0.532, p=0.0167). Self-reported vaccination rates 191 may serve as a surrogate marker for herd immunity 27, 28
However, in years with a low vaccine effectiveness (Table S4 ) this association may be weaker.

In order to monitor antibody titres over time in a healthy population across the city, we recruited Table S1 ). Before the 2016/2017 influenza season, we observed 211 that across all urban quarters a median of 21% (IQR 17-28.5%) had seroprotective antibody levels

(defined as hemagglutination inhibition titres equal or more than 1:40 31 ) ( Figure 3A) . Again, urban 213 quarters with lower socioeconomic scores also showed low seroprotection rates (e.g. Matthaeus,

Breite, Kleinhueningen and Klybeck) ( Figure S6A ). Urban quarters with higher socioeconomic 215 scores showed a median seroprotection rate of 26.1%, whereas those with lower socioeconomic 216 scores showed a median seroprotection rate of 14.6% (p=0.05). Blood donors with influenza 217 vaccination showed significant higher H3N2 specific HI titers in comparison to people who were 218 not vaccinated (p<0.0001; Figure S6B ). Similar to the survey, in this cohort net income was Table S5 ). This visualization can be
(WE) were more identical in comparison to other urban quarters (p<0.005, Figure 3C ).

Transmission events within the same urban quarter were explored. Interestingly, two urban 284 quarters -Gundeldingen (GU) and Vorstaedte (VO) -showed influenza isolates that were 285 significantly more related to other isolates from within the same urban quarter than to isolates 286 from other quarters or outside of Basel (p<0.001, Figure 3C ). These two urban quarters show a 287 low socioeconomic score and lower pre-seasonal seroprotection rate. Phylogenetic cluster size 288 did not correlate with any socioeconomic factors (p=n.s.).
Each year influenza infects millions of people around the globe 36, 37
This would allow us to address more and account for a greater variety of population segments 347 and help to identify potential drivers of transmission.

We next reconstructed the phylogenetic trees of all initial clusters by using the full genomes of all 751 samples from the initial clusters. We fixed the evolutionary rates to be equal to the mean 752 evolutionary rates as estimated using the methods above. As a population model, we used a 753 constant coalescent model with an estimated effective population size that was shared among all 754 initial clusters. We then estimated a distribution of phylogenies for each initial cluster, assuming 755 that all segments share the same phylogeny. As estimated in the previous analysis, reassortment
will not bias evolutionary rates.

Local cluster identification. To identify sets of sequences from Basel that were likely to have been 759 transmitted locally, we reconstructed the geographic origins of lineages that were introduced into 760

Basel. Therefore, we used the phylogenetic tree distributions for each initial cluster to reconstruct 761 the ancestral states using parsimony. We made some modifications to the standard algorithm for 762 parsimony ancestral state reconstruction to reflect our prior assumption, that Basel is unlikely to

BIBREF0.title: Continental synchronicity of human influenza virus epidemics

FIGREF0.text: . Similarly, at the level of an urban quarter, 192 herd immunity strongly affected the risk of acquiring influenza-like illness during the 2015/2016 193 season. Urban quarters with a high self-reported vaccination rate showed a significantly lower 194 likelihood of influenza-like illness of the surveyed population compared to urban quarters with a 195 low vaccine rate (R 2 =0.61, p=0.01; Figure 2D). However, no protective effect against common 196 cold was observed (Figure 2E, p=0.56). Therefore, unvaccinated people living in the Matthaeus 197 quarter (MA) show an 8-times higher probability of contracting an influenza-like illness than those 198 vaccinated while in the Bruderholz quarter (BR) unvaccinated people only show a 1.2-fold higher 199 risk. We again observed the association of self-reported influenza-like illness and vaccination 200 rates (in % of returned survey) at the level of individual statistical blocks (r=-0.1182, p=0.007).

FIGREF3.text: 252interactively explored using the narrative functions of Nextstrain. The diversity of European 253 influenza isolates was fully represented by the isolates collected from patients living in Basel and 254 the surrounding area. In addition, also at the level of urban quarters and statistical blocks, we 10 observed the same high intermixture and diversity. Although the socioeconomic scores differ 256 between urban quarters and statistical blocks, we did not observe an association we further explored viral transmission clusters in more detail. Based on previously published 262 mutation rates 34,35 , we assumed that influenza viruses accumulate an average of 10 single263 nucleotide polymorphisms during a single influenza season. Viral strains with a genetic 264 relatedness within this range were assigned as being in the same transmission cluster. A 265 sequence, which is more than 10 single nucleotide polymorphisms different from any other 266 sequence was ignored, so that a transmission cluster contains at least 2 viral strains. The 54 267 transmission clusters identified (Figure 3B) incorporated 547/663 influenza strains, each 268 comprising a minimum of two isolates, a median of three isolates, ranging from 2 to 111 within 269 and outside of the city (Figure S7D). Only 116 (17.5%) cases could not be linked to another 270 individual. Most of the transmission clusters contained samples from more than one urban 271quarter, and only a few clusters were predominantly located within a single urban quarter (

FIGREF5.text: For each statistical block demographic data was obtained from the Statistics Office of the 379 Canton Basel-City: net income in CHF, population per ha, and living space in m 2 per capita. These 380 socioeconomic factors contributed to an overall socioeconomic score for every statistical block 381 ranging from minimum three to maximum fifteen.

FIGREF6.text: Survey on ILI and vaccination. We selected urban quarters for the survey a priori, based on 384 identified diversity in their socioeconomic structure(Figure S2A-D). We translated the 385 questionnaire into the six most common spoken languages in the selected urban quarters in order 386 to reach a maximum population. The survey was distributed within one week after the end of the 387 influenza season. Of the 30,000 questionnaires distributed in 10 urban quarters,8,149 (27.1%)    388 were returned and fulfilled the quality criteria for subsequent analysis. Returned questionnaires 389 were quality controlled and the data was entered into a database. Questionnaires were excluded 390 when no information of influenza-like illness or vaccination status was reported. Influenza-like 391 illness was defined according by the WHO as a combination of self-reported fever, coughing, and 392 illness of less than ten days 41,42 . The questionnaires allowed the option of self-identifying one's 393 place of residence within a statistical block within the urban quarter.

FIGREF7.text: Relative risks for influenza-like illness and influenza vaccination were estimated by uni-and 395 multivariable Poisson regression with robust error variance. To deal with possible confounding, 396 all variables found to differ significantly in univariable analyses between participants with and 397 without ILI and with and without influenza vaccination, respectively, were included in the 398 multivariable generalized linear models. A Bonferroni-adjusted p-value threshold was applied to 399 select variables for inclusion into the multivariable models. Poisson regression models using 400 stepwise forward and backward selection were applied to identify variables independently 401 associated with both primary outcomes.

FIGREF8.text: 403 influencing both the risk for influenza-like illness acquisition and vaccination uptake, analyses 404 regarding individual risk factors were complemented by multivariable, multilevel mixed-effects 405 generalized linear models. The Pearson and deviance goodness-of-fit tests were performed to 406 assess the fit of the data to a Poisson distribution in the final regression models. Analyses were 407 performed using Stata statistical software, version 15.1 (Stata Corp, College Station, Texas,

FIGREF11.text: Influenza cases in Basel 2013-2018. The graph shows the distribution of PCR 556 confirmed influenza cases in the City of Basel at the resolution of statistical enumeration blocks. 557 (A) Geographical clustering of influenza infections. A kernel density estimation across all five 558 influenza seasons from 2013/2014 to 2017/2018 was used to analyse the influenza case 559 distribution across the city. The 4 th and 5 th share of the kernels were visualized. The red clouds 560 show Influenza A cases and the blue clouds Influenza B cases. (B) As A, with underlying 561 socioeconomic score for each housing block visualized, ranging from 3 to 15. The score consists 562 of three individual factors: population density per ha, living space per person in m 2 and net income 563 in CHF. The natural break of the socioeconomic scores were used and visualized with three 564 different shades of grey. Clusters of influenza correlate with lower socioeconomic scores. (C) 565 Case load across representative examples of urban quarters (Bruderholz as less densely 566 populated and Gundeldingen as more densely populated). Each red dot represents an Influenza 567 A case. In order to not show the actual address of a patient, we set the dots in the middle of the 568 statistical block. (D) We combined Google Earth satellite images with maps showing the kernel 569 density estimates of influenza cases to indicate building density. Red clouds show Influenza A 570 cases and blue Influenza B cases, correlating with building density, reflecting population density.571 (E) Influenza A virus incidence rates of season 2016/2017 per 1000 inhabitants of each statistical 572 housing block. (F) Influenza B virus incidence rates of season 2016/2017 per 1000 inhabitants of 573 each statistical housing block. (G) Multivariable Poisson regression analysis to explore the 574 association of influenza virus incidence (per 1000 inhabitants corrected for the population of each 575 housing block) and each socioeconomic factor. Average influenza incidences for the seasons 576 2013/2014 to 2017/2018 are shown. Net income relative risk per 1 CHF; populations density per 577 person per ha; living density per person in m 2 Survey on self-reported Influenza-like illness and vaccination over season 580 2015/2016. (A) Distribution of self-reported influenza-like illness cases according to the WHO 581 definition 41 over the 10 selected urban quarters. The number of Influenza-like illness cases per 582 incoming answers is expressed as percentage value for each quarter. The blue colour range is 583 according to natural breaks and ranges from 3.4% to 7%. (B) Self-reported vaccine rates (on a 584 per person basis / all received surveys for the specific urban quarter). Natural breaks between urban quarters are shown in different shades of green, ranging from 18.7% to 32.2%. (C) shows a correlation at the levels of urban quarter in the aggregate. (D) Self-reported vaccine rates 588 against influenza and the likelihood for ILI, using logistic regression, shows an inverse correlation. 589 (E) Self-reported vaccine rates against influenza and the likelihood of common cold, Influenza antibody titres and whole genome sequencing of influenza viruses to 593 explore transmission between urban quarter levels. (A) Pre-seasonal antibody titres against 594 H3N2 from healthy blood donors in the 2016/2017 influenza season measured using 595 hemagglutination inhibition assay. Distribution of seroprotection (defined as titre >1:40) are 596 visualized as percentages using natural breaks. (B) Cluster analysis of each influenza case 597 genome during the 2016/2017 season. Each dot represents a sequenced influenza virus isolate. 598 Colour reflects the host address by specific urban quarter. Each horizontal line corresponds to a 599 local transmission cluster of influenza viruses. Three representative clusters 19, 31 and 53 are 600 detailed on the right using maximum likelihood trees indicating the complexity of transmission 601 clusters across time and urban quarters. (C) Exchange of influenza viruses throughout the city.602Red lines connecting two quarters indicates isolates that are identical within the same 603 transmission cluster, with the line width and colour intensity indicating the number of isolates in 604 that cluster shared by the connected quarters. Therefore, they indicate the level of transmissions 605 between two quarters. When correcting for multiple comparison, only the transmission within the 606 same urban quarters remained statistically significant (p<0.05), which is indicated as a coloured 607 bar at the basis of the circle. The darker the colour the more significant the association.

FIGREF15.text: All box blots show median and interquartile ranges. Whiskers indicate 10-90% percentile with 673 outliers. (C) The percentage of cumulative H3N2 specific hemagglutination inhibition antibody 674 titres is shown, again highlighting the difference between PCR positive and negative titres. (D) 675 Number of clusters and cluster size are shown, from the whole genome sequencing data. More 676 than 50% of the clusters comprise five or fewer viruses. 677 Cluster analysis of each influenza case genome during the 2016/2017 season based 679 on the phylodynamic model. Each dot represents a sequenced influenza virus isolate. Colour 680 reflects the host address by specific urban quarter. Each horizontal line corresponds to a local 681 transmission cluster of influenza viruses. Three representative clusters A, B and C are detailed 682 on the right using maximum likelihood trees indicating the complexity of transmission clusters 683 across time and urban quarters. selection: stepwise, pe(0.05): glm y x1 x2 x3 x(…) ,fam (poisson) link(model (mixed effects generalized linear model) 717 meglm y x1 x2 x3 x(…) , II urban quarter:, fam (poisson) link(log)nolog eform 718 Group variable : urban quarter Phylodynamic model for transmission.720In addition to the previously described clustering model based on the number of single nucleotide 721 polymorphisms, we have also applied a clustering method based on a clustering based on nucleotide differences. We combined the Basel sequences with a global726 sample of sequences (downloaded on 17th July 2018) from https://www.gisaid.org which had 727 been sampled between 1st January 2016 and 31st December 2017 for which at least the 728 segments HA, NA and MP were available. We then calculated the average nucleotide difference 729 between any of the sequences and the sequences from Basel. To split the dataset into 730 manageable pieces, we first grouped any two sequences from Basel together if they were within 731 an average nucleotide difference of 0.0025 per position. When the full genome for two sequences 732 was available, this would correspond to about 32 different positions on the full genome. For an 733 average clock rate of 0.005 mutations per site per year, 32 differences correspond to a pairwise 734 phylogenetic distance of about 0.5 years. Sets of sequences from Basel were only split into two 735 groups if the two closest related sequences of each group exceeded this criterium. Based on this 736 initial grouping, we added global sequences to each cluster if they were at maximum 0.0025/2 737 mutations away from any of the sequences from Basel. Factor 2 was used to reduce the number 738 of global sequences in each of these initial clusters.739 740Phylogenetic trees of initial clusters. We next estimated rates of evolution for each segment using 741 the SRD06 model 60 and a strict clock model, from 200 full genome sequences sampled in 742 California, New York and Europe between 2010 and 2015, using Beast 2.5 61 . Apart from this, 743 these sequences were not otherwise used in the analysis, and as such are an independent 744 dataset. We allowed each segment to have its own phylogeny in order to avoid the possibility of 745 a reassortment biasing the estimates of evolutionary rates. Each of the segments, as well as the 746 first two and third codon position was allowed to have its own rate scaler. We ran ten independent 747 Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) chains each for 10 8 iterations and then combined them after 748 a burn-in of 10%. These estimated evolutionary rates are long-term rates of influenza A/H3N2.

FIGREF16.text: 763act as a relevant source of influenza on a global scale. If any descendent was not in Basel, the 764 node was classified as "not Basel". Since the influenza season covers only a few months, we 765 additionally assumed that lineages are unlikely to persist in Basel for more than 5 weeks (0.1 766 years) without being sampled. To reflect this assumption, we classified internal nodes that are 767 more than 0.1 years from a sample from Basel to be either outside of Basel, or to be in an unknown768 location. We then defined sequences to be in the same local cluster if all their ancestors are 769 inferred to be in Basel. Local clusters are obtained for each iteration of the MCMC. The exact 770 workflow, including BEAST2 input files can be found at https://github.com/nicfel/Flu-771 Basel/LocalClusters. While alternative model-based approaches exist to reconstruct locations of 772 internal nodes 62 , these approaches themselves make strict assumptions that are violated when 773 studying the spread of diseases on a city scale. Also, it is further unknown how well they perform 774 when migration between individual locations is very strong. From the grouping of sequences into 775 local clusters as described above, sequences were classified into different local clusters over the 776 course of the MCMC.

TABREF1.text: . Historically, human pandemics have had devastating outcomes, and preventive measures should have high priority.Our results reflect an unprecedented large and dense datasets of PCR-confirmed influenza Our study has certain limitations. First, in the survey, a more research-interested population may 305 have replied to the questionnaire. In particular, 37.9% of males replied to the survey, whereas in diagnostic using PCR confirmation, we cannot exclude some recruitment bias, that particular people with a specific demographic background are more likely to be included at a tertiary 312 healthcare centre. In order to compensate for such a bias, we also included data from other study influenza will not seek healthcare. Thus, some transmission links will always remain unknown.For more detailed analyses, future studies would need to include hundreds of samples with high resolution epidemiological data across multiple influenza seasons to study the changing patterns of transmission over multiple years. In addition, the transmission events across urban quarters 12 are highly complex, driven by mobility of people living within a city and commuters, place of working, and changing antibody titres of exposed patients in each year. Although we have asked where a person works, we were not able to collect sufficient data for this question -only 24.6% provided details and people working in the same statistical block were very rare (<5%).knowledge gained with our study can help to tailor public health measures such as urban 337 vaccination programs to urban influenza hotspots and not just to selected target groups (e.g. highrisk populations with chronic illness). National vaccination recommendations often only include a selected population, e.g. health care workers, patients with comorbidities or particular age groups.

We also thank the study nurse team of the Clinical trial unit (Silke Purschke and Karin Wild) for their excellent organization and coordination 512 of the patient recruitment. We thank Magdalena Schneider, Rosamaria Vesco, ChristineKiessling, Elisabeth Schultheiss, and Clarisse Straub for excellent technical assistance of genome sequencing. We also thank Dr. Vladimira Hinic (University Hospital Basel) and Prof. Emma Slack 515 (ETH Zurich) for critically reading the manuscript. We thank Andrew Jermy for excellent feedback 516 and critical review on the manuscript (Germinate, UK).
